topic.title: Why don't we embed the TokenScript's hash in Smart Contract's
topic.shortdesc: Currently, a TokenScript is "trusted" by a smart contract through the TokenScript's signing key. Why don't we chuck tokenscript on an IPFS and keep hash of this code is embedded into contract?

body.p: In fact earlier TokenScripts were designed like that. However, as we experimented with TokenScript on various types of tokens, we found that the frequency of updating is quite high. Since TokenScript has the Cards, which is the interface for Token Contracts, trivial things like correcting spelling on user's interface adds transactions to the already crowded Ethereum network.

We also observed that the roles emerge in Token teams. Those who have admin access to a smart contract, therefore can update the "hash" included in the contract for TS, are often not the same persons responsible for editing and updating TokenScripts. If the trust is expressed by file hash, not by keys, the person responsible for updating TokenScript would repeatedly ask the person with admin access to send new transactions.
Furthermore, AlphaWallet created many TokenScripts for existing Tokens, who would express trust towards AlphaWallet's TokenScript authors but does not want to be called upon in day to day updates.
